#02 Eric Juengst — Medical Genetics and Reproductive Decision-Making

 

Shownotes

About Eric Juengst

Background and Early ELSI Frameworks

  • ELSI (Ethical, Legal, and Social Implications) Research Program
  • Human Genome Project launched in 1990
  • French Anderson
  • Genotypic vs. phenotypic prevention and the goals of genetic medicine (3:26)

The Shadow of Eugenics (6:54)

  • Nathaniel Comfort’s The Science of Human Perfection
  • Genetic meliorism and the meliorative impulse (7:58)
  • Reproductive decision-making and pressures (10:37)

Rhetorical Shifts in Genetic Medicine (12:46)

  • Juengst et al. on rhetorical reform in genomic medicine
  • Personalized medicine vs. precision medicine
  • MAGs: medically actionable genes (16:00)
  • A semiquantitative framework for evaluating clinical actionability of incidental or secondary findings
  • Genes aren’t very good germs
  • BRCA and prophylactic double mastectomy (19:52)

Direct to Consumer (DTC) Genetic Testing (21:45)

  • Article: Consumer genomics will change your life, whether you get tested or not
  • The role of MD’s in the age of DTC genetic testing
  • Genetic fortunetelling vs. genetic forecasting (23:23)

Pressures and Equilibria in Reproductive Decision Making (24:40)

  • Postnatal vs prenatal vs preconception prevention
  • Dor Yeshorim and Tay Sachs
  • Moral permissibility vs. prescribability
  • De facto reproductive decisions (32:33)
  • Iceland and prenatal screening for Down Syndrome
  • Disease as a spectrum

Dilemmas of Reproductive Decision Making (37:48)

  • Principal-agent problem of reproductive decision-making
  • Collective action problem
  • “Great Minds Think Different: Preserving Cognitive Diversity in an Age of Gene Editing” (38:22)
  • “Polygenic risk scores for schizophrenia and bipolar disorder predict creativity”
  • Is genetic diversity an inherent good? (40:20)
  • HLA gene, which codes for the major histocompatability complex
  • Crop monocultures {:target=”_blank”}
  • Social arrangements for a world where everyone can flourish—what sort of special dispensations are we willing to make to accomodate the full spectrum of genetic diversity?

Enhancement vs. Prevention (43:44)

  • Myostatin
  • Muscular dystrophy
  • Jacked bodybuilder dogs
  • Immunization as enhancement

Intuitions Around Enhancement

  • Rasmus Nielsen and Xinzhu Wei’s retracted CCR5 paper
  • Plomin and Von Stumm, “The New Genetics of Intelligence”
  • Education’s effect on intelligence
  • “Mainstream science on intelligence”
  • “Beneficence, Determinism and Justice: An Engagement with the Argument for the Genetic Selection of Intelligence”
